text: The ground suddenly shook as a rock-armored beast burst from the soil, its glowing green eyes scattering the forest birds with a thunderous growl.
Instinctively, I grabbed my backpack and raised it to block. In that same instant, the creature’s claws came crashing down. The impact was so strong it forced me back two steps.
But that block slowed its attack just enough.
Alicia dashed forward, her sword flashing like lightning. The blade struck the beast square in the chest. With a guttural roar, it staggered and collapsed—its rocky shell crumbling into ash.

I stared at the claw marks on my torn backpack, frozen for a few seconds. Alicia sheathed her sword and turned toward me, her eyes lingering for a moment before she smiled—a small smile, but enough to make me breathe easier.
“Quick reflexes,” she said lightly. “Didn’t think you’d actually block that.”
“Just lucky,” I replied with a wry grin, holding up the ruined pack. “Looks like it’s tougher than me.”
“Luck counts as skill too.” She gave my shoulder a gentle pat. “But next time, don’t take the hit head-on. Those things are stronger than you think.”
She crouched down, examining the scorched patch of earth. Her brows knit slightly. “These monsters aren’t natural. They’re ‘Residual Dreams’—echoes left behind by the dead.”
“Residual Dreams?” I repeated, still catching my breath.
“Yes. In places where wars were fought and lives were lost, the ground absorbs their final emotions. Over time, those emotions take form.”
She stood up, her gaze softening, her voice gentler than before.
“But don’t worry. As long as I’m here, they won’t get close.”
She extended her hand toward me. I hesitated for a moment, then took it. Smiling, she pulled me to my feet. “Come on, the market’s just ahead.”
A breeze swept through the trees. Sunlight glinted off her silver hair, so bright I couldn’t look away.
